5.2.19  5:51 pm   4.30.19  10:27 am It's like how you have several parts of your brain (limbic system, frontal lobe, occipital lobe, etc.) and even if some of them act independently of the others, "you" are still "aware of" what they do (create emotion, make judgements, process vision, respectively). And, in the case of, say, the occipital lobe, even if the neurons never receive signals from each other directly, the lobe is still "aware" of what the neurons do (aware meaning affecting behavior. In this case, what the neurons do determines how the lobe behaves, i.e. what it communicates to the other parts of the brain, and so we say the lobe is "aware of" the neurons' actions. Same applies for part of your brain affecting "you").
The ABC scenario is a just simple example of this Russian-nesting-doll of consciousness, where higher levels are aware of the thoughts of lower levels, but not vice-versa. My theory is that, just as a human has independent parts yet feels like a single experiencing mind and not like millions of tiny neuron minds, so too may there be a higher level of consciousness that feels like me and only me, you and only you, Benedict Cumberbatch and only Cumberbatch, â€¦ , and perhaps some non-person thoughts exclusive to the higher-level-consciousness.
That's what I mean by everyone is everyone else. By the theory, we are all just one entity that experiences many localized, I-am-me-and-noone-else perspectives. Of course I feel like me, and you feel like you. But that feeling of individual identity does not mean that our experiences are not just the thoughts of one single entity.

5.1.19  12:33 am   one of my biggest problems when combining melody with chords is that ending a melodic phrase by going M3 -> 1 is one of the strongest sounding melodic resolutions, but the strongest harmonic resolutions I know (V7->I, bII7->I, iv6->I) all do not work well with the M3rd of the tonic chord included (at least when the blending is clear enough to hear the dissonance). I know V13 is a thing, but I always think that sounds weird unless the 7th is lower than the 13th, which usually makes the chord sound muddy.

The best way I've found is iii with the 5th of the tonic scale in the bass, but that never is quite as satisfying as I want it to be.

      Do you have a go-to for this situation? I know in And The Day Goes On, you just did a I chord with the 5th in the bass going to a normal I chord with lots of voices moving down and it totally worked there

      but like iii/5th

      it leaves me with a bit of harmonic blue balls when I try to apply it in general.
